Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Optimal Statistics for Redshifted 21 cm Observations of the Reionization Epoch
Award.AbstractNarration:
One important new frontier of cosmology is the Epoch of Reionization (EoR), marking the time when the Universe's first luminous objects formed and the time of the final phase of cosmological formation of structure in the Universe. Most investigators seek to observe the EoR by detecting neutral hydrogen gas of the intergalactic medium (IGM) through its signature in the redshifted 21-cm spectral line. While a variety of projects are currently underway to detect the EoR signal, thermal noise will dominant the signal and will require careful statistical analysis of the observational data to infer the statistical nature of the EoR signal. Unfortunately, one of the statistical techniques employed will be to characterize power spectrum of the EoR signal even though this signal is expected to be non-Gaussian.

The intent of this project is to systematically explore statistics that reach far beyond the power spectrum technique. The investigators will compute radiative transfer simulations of reionization for a wide variety of well-defined theoretical models. Expected thermal noise, foreground corruption, and instrumental distortions will next be added to the simulations to produce complete simulations of observational sky maps in 21 cm. The investigators will next measure a range of statistics on these simulated observational maps to characterize the most robust useful information obtainable from the EoR signal.

Educationally, an undergraduate will receive support and mentoring at one institution, and graduate students at two institutions will receive support and mentoring. An important feature of student training in this project is the interdisciplinary nature of the research including complex statistical analysis, analytical and numerical simulations, instrumental modeling, and astrophysics. The student experience will also emphasize the interconnection between experimental conditions and scientific analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funded by this grant, the PI and collaborators developed new techniques to analyze upcoming radio frequency observations of the Epoch of Reionization (EoR). A key unexplored frontier in observational and theoretical cosmology is to understand the properties of the universe between 400,000 years and one billion years after the big bang. Notably, the first galaxies formed in this time period, perhaps a few hundred million years after the big bang. These early galaxies strongly influenced the gas in their surroundings by emitting ultraviolet light and ionizing “bubbles” of hydrogen gas around them. These ionized bubbles grew, merged, and eventually filled the entire volume of the universe in a process known as reionization. Understanding this process will constrain the properties of the first luminous sources, and fill in a significant gap in our story of structure formation, whereby the universe transitions from simple initial conditions to its present day complexity.

One of the most promising ways to study the EoR is to make use of the 21 cm line from neutral hydrogen. The spin of the electron in a hydrogen atom can flip relative to the proton spin, while emitting a photon of 21 cm wavelength. As 21 cm emission propagates to us, it stretches in wavelength (“redshifts”) with the expansion of the universe and remaining neutral hydrogen clouds from the EoR can be observed in emission relative to the cosmic microwave background radiation at wavelengths of around two meters.  Numerous current and upcoming surveys aim to make the first detection of redshifted 21 cm emission from the EoR. These observations face numerous challenges, especially strong foreground emission - mostly from our own galaxy - that is around one hundred thousand times brighter than the cosmological signal. Fortunately, this foreground contamination should be separable from the EoR emission since the foregrounds are smooth functions of frequency while the cosmological signal has strong frequency variations.

In addition, noise in the upcoming radio observations will prevent early generations of redshifted 21 cm surveys from making detailed maps of the reionization process, and forthcoming detections will be mostly statistical in nature. An important problem here is to identify the best statistics to measure from upcoming data sets. Most previous work has focused solely on a single statistical measure, the power spectrum of 21 cm brightness fluctuations. However, the 21 cm signal during reionization is expected to be strongly non-Gaussian with large ionized regions of essentially zero signal intermixed with emission from surrounding neutral gas. In this case, the power spectrum is an incomplete and likely sub-optimal statistic.

In this work, we developed a complementary matched filter algorithm that directly identifies likely ionized regions in upcoming noisy data sets. In this approach, one correlates known “template” signals describing ionized regions of varying size with the noisy data to determine whether the template signal is present in the noisy data. We tested this approach on mock simulated data and found it to be promising. We further considered the prospects of combining information regarding the location of likely ionized regions with measurements of galaxy properties using the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST). We showed that the radio observations can be fruitfully combined with the JWST measurements to explore how galaxy properties depend on their large scale ionization environment. In addition, we quantified the impact of primordial non-Gaussianity on the redshifted 21 cm signal. Finally, we developed two new techniques for determining the ionization history from current quasar absorption line data sets, which can be applied to sharpen our 21 cm predictions and to refine the observing strategy for these surveys.<...
